intro: Gnidia imbricata var. denudata, commonly known as the naked-stemmed gnidia, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its slender, often hairless stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of yellow flowers that bloom in spring, followed by small, woody fruits. It is typically found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Due to its unique morphology and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
